headline: Paid Notice: Deaths NELSON, KENNETH

(Importer and National Sales Organization - Office Products). Board of Directors, Staten Island Bancorp, Inc. Staten Island, N.Y. (Now Sovereign Bank). Director, First Fortis Life Assurance Co. Syracuse, N.Y. 13220. Director, Bankers American Life Assurance Co. Pearl River, N.Y. 10965. Former Director, American Centurion Life Assurance Co. (Subsidiary of American Express) American Express Tower, World Financial Center, New York, N.Y. Former Director, Norton & Son, Inc. Elder & Jenks, Inc. and The Muralo Company, Inc. Bayonne, N.J. headline: Paid Notice: Deaths FISHER, CHARLES T.
summary: FISHER--Charles Thomas III. Grosse Pointe Farms resident Charles Thomas "Chick" Fisher III, former chairman, president and CEO of NBD Bancorp Inc., died Sunday, June 15, 2014. He was 84. Mr. Fisher was born November 22, 1929, in Detroit to Charles Thomas Fisher Jr. and Elizabeth Briggs Fisher and was a grandson of Charles T. Fisher Sr. co-founder of Fisher Body, which later became part of General Motors Corp., and Walter O. Briggs, who founded the Briggs Manufacturing Company, a maker of automobile bodies, and who owned the Detroit Tigers baseball team. Mr. Fisher graduated in 1947 from Portsmouth Priory School in Rhode Island; Georgetown University in 1951 and earned an MBA from Harvard University in 1953 and an honorary Doctorate from Georgetown University in 1990. He began work as an accountant with Touche, Ross, Bailey & Smart, and became a certified public accountant in Michigan in 1957. He joined NBD as an assistant vice president in 1958, became president in 1972 and chairman in 1982. He retired in 1993. Mr. Fisher was active in professional and community organizations including serving as a director of American Airlines, DTE (Detroit Edison), General Motors, Hiram Walker, American Broadcasting Company, National Intergroup, Jannock Ltd, Mackinac Bridge Authority, and the Georgetown University Board of Regents (Founding Member) and Board of Visitors (Chairman). He also was a member of the Country Club of Detroit, Detroit Athletic Club, Grosse Pointe Club, Bloomfield Hills Country Club, Little Traverse Yacht Club, St. Andrews Club, Question Club, Alfalfa Club, New York Yacht Club,The Key Largo Anglers Club, Delray Beach Yacht Club, the Links Club, Old Club, Wequetonsing Club, Little Harbor Club, Golf Stream Golf Club, Golf Stream Bath and Tennis Club, and the Yondetega Club. Mr. Fisher is survived by his wife, Margaret Elizabeth "Beth" Keegin Fisher, whom he married June 18, 1952; children, Margaret Elizabeth "Lisa" Fisher Jones (Macy); Curtis William Fisher, Lawrence P. "Larry" Fisher II (Maria Elena) and Mary Florence "Mimi" Fisher Hickey (John). He was predeceased by his son, Charles T. Fisher IV. Mr. Fisher also is survived by his grandchildren, Kristin Fisher Allen, Elizabeth Briggs Jones Coleman, Charles T. Fisher V, Curtis William Fisher Jr., Marta Cristina Fisher, John Keegin Fisher, Keegin Marie Fisher, Emily Ryan Hickey, Kathryn Keegin Hickey and Alison Briggs Hickey; four great-grandchildren; siblings, Mary Elizabeth Fisher, R.S.C.J., Fred J. Fisher II (Juelle), Jane F. McDonnell (Richard C. Tucker), Walter B. Fisher (Sandy), Sarah F. Champion (Robert) and John A. Fisher (Didi). A funeral Mass was celebrated on Thursday, June 19, at St. Paul on the Lake Catholic Church, 157 Lakeshore, Grosse Pointe Farms, MI. Share a memory at http://verheyden.org

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ROWE, GEORGE, JR.
summary: ROWE--George, Jr.,died August 14, 2014 at the age of 92, following a long illness. He was the senior partner of the law firm of Fulton Rowe & Hart LLP and was the longtime President of The Ambrose Monell Foundation, Inc. and of The G. Unger Vetlesen Foundation, Inc. Mr. Rowe graduated from Yale University in 1943 where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. After graduation, he served in the United States Navy until 1946 aboard the U.S.S. Birmingham (CL 62) in the South Pacific, where he rose to the rank of lieutenant. After the War, he attended Columbia University Law School, and graduated in 1948. While at Columbia Law, he was recognized as a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar, and was elected an editor of the Columbia Law Review for the 1947-1948 term. Following law school, he joined the firm of Fulton, Walter & Halley (now Fulton, Rowe & Hart LLP). Mr. Rowe served as president and director of Stanrock Uranium Mines Limited and as a director of its successor, Denison Mines Limited. Mr. Rowe also served as a director of International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Foster Wheeler Corporation and Axe Houghton Mutual Funds. He served for many years as a director and as the Vice President and Secretary of the van Ameringen Foundation, Inc. He is survived by his wife, Joyce C. Rowe, and their daughter Zoe X. Rowe, and also by his three children by a prior marriage, John G. Rowe, Julia T. Rowe and Katharine F. Rowe.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WILLIAMS, DAVID T
summary: WILLIAMS--David T. Internationally renowned interior designer for the hotel and hospitality industry for over 65 years peacefully passed away at his home in New York City on July 5, 2014. Born in Burlington, IA on April 10, 1918, David, a Veteran of World War II began his career as an interior decorator at Marshall Field & Company in Chicago, Il. It was in 1946 when hotel magnet, Conrad N. Hilton through Marshall Fields hired David to decorate the Stevens Hotel in Chicago (renamed The Conrad Hilton in 1951). Impressed by his extraordinary talent and creative ability, Hilton hired David to work at the Hilton Hotels Corporation as Vice President and Director Statler Hilton Studios. When Conrad Hilton purchased The Waldorf-Astoria in 1949, David moved to New York to work on the decor of both The Waldorf and The Plaza Hotels. David's genius for design was soon found in hotels around the world. His success continued and in 1958 he established his own company David T. Williams Inc. His business flourished with the addition of new hotel companies and clients; Loews, Canadian Pacific, Forte, Hyatt, the corporate offices of Hilton Hotels, the Cornell Club in New York to name a few. In November 1996 in celebration of his 50 years of decorating for Hilton Hotels, David was inducted into The Waldorf-Astoria Distinguished Alumni. On the occasion Barron Hilton, the son of Conrad and former Chairman of Hilton Hotels Corporation wrote to David "the standards that you set at the many flagship Hilton Hotels still stand today as examples of your outstanding interior design work. The mark of design excellence which you have left imprinted throughout the world has been a great tradition in the hotel industry and will be long remembered." David was preceded by his parents - Nora and Edward Williams; his brother, Clarence Williams and sister, Lillian Gamet. He leaves his brother William E. Williams and sister-in-law Doddie Williams of Spokane, WA along with several nieces and nephews. As per his wish, David has been cremated and will be buried with his parents in Missouri. Later there will be a gathering of friends to remember David T. and his wonderful life.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths YATES, DOUGLAS T.
summary: YATES--Douglas T., of New York City, on August 16, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Titus Yates, devoted father of Douglas T. Yates, Jr. (Mary Caryl) of New Haven, CT, Timothy T. Yates (Kay) of Rye, NY, and L. Randall Yates (the late Hope Lloyd) and Margaret Yates Thorne (Nate), of New York City. Adored grandfather of Nate and Nicholas Thorne, and Hope Starr, Lawrence Jr., Tim (Alexis), Chris (Angela), Ted, Katie, Doug (Kerri), Brian (Marci) and Scott (Mackenzie) Yates. Loving great-grandfather of Max, Charlie, Campbell, Jade, Summer, Dougie, Eddie, Gaby, Oscar and Lydia Yates. Doug was a graduate of Culver Military Academy and Williams College. He served his Country during World War II as a Major in the US Army Signal Corps, then was employed as the Executive Vice-President and Director of Republic Pictures Corp., Chairman of Seaboard Associates Inc., Partner at White, Weld and Co., and Vice-President at Merrill Lynch. Doug was a Trustee of The Buckley School, and was a Trustee and Founder of The Episcopal School in New York City. He also served as a member of the Vestry of St. James Church and the International Center for the Disabled, was a Trustee of the Hospital Chaplaincy and The General Theological Seminary, and was Chairman of the Board of Foreign Parishes of The Episcopal Church. He was a long-time Trustee of Lenox Hill Hospital, and was Chairman of The United Hospital Fund and Vice-Chairman of The Greater New York Fund of United Way. Doug was a Knight Hospitaller of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem, and was proud to have received The United Hospital Distinguished Director Award for 28 years of Distinguished Service to Hospitals and the United Hospital Distinguished Trustee Award for Extraordinary Service to Lenox Hill Hospital. He was a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club, NYC, Southward Ho C.C., Bay Shore, NY, and Gasparilla Inn Golf Club, Boca Grande, FL. A Memorial Service at St. James Church will be held at 11:00am on September 12, 2014. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Buckley School, 113 East 73rd Street or The Episcopal School in New York City, 35 East 69th Street. Internment will be private.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ELKUS, CHRISTOPHER
summary: ELKUS--Christopher James, passed away peacefully at his home in Ligonier, PA on Wednesday, July 16th following a long and progressive illness. He was born in New York City on February 7, 1941 and was raised in Pittsburgh, PA, the son of James H. Elkus and Lenore R. Elkus. His mother was a founder of WQED-TV in Pittsburgh and a Distinguished Daughter of Pennsylvania. His father was an industrial engineer. His paternal grandfather, the Hon. Abram I. Elkus, served as US Ambassador to Turkey under President Wilson and as a judge on the New York State Court of Appeals. His maternal grandmother, Hulda Lashanska, was a celebrated American concert soprano. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Gretchen M. Elkus of Ligonier, PA, his son James M. EIkus and grand-daughter Sonya R. Elkus of New York City and his sister Peggy H. Elkus of Pittsburgh. His brother Jonathan H. Elkus of Geneva, Switzerland died in 2003. He is also survived by his stepchildren William M. Duryea of Tampa, FL and his children William, Peter and Andrew Duryea and Melissa Duryea Lewis of San Anselmo, CA and her children Olivia and Augusta Lewis. Mr. Elkus was a graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, Yale University and New York University School of Business. He resided in New York City throughout most of his adult life where he worked as an investment manager for large corporations and organizations such as the United Nations. He was dedicated member of his community and served as President of the Lenox Hi Neighborhood House, a multi-service organization that has served people in need on the East Side of Manhattan and on Roosevelt Island for over 120 years. He later founded Waterford Capital Management upon his retirement to Ligonier, PA. He was an avid sportsman, traveler and lover of the outdoors. While at St. Paul's he excelled at football, rowing and wrestling. Following his competitive sports years he enjoyed skiing, fishing, hunting, golf, squash and tennis. He was a member of the Racquet & Tennis Club and the Brook Club in New York, the Piping Rock Club on Long Island and the Rolling Rock Club in Ligonier, Pennsylvania. His family extends their warmest thanks to his doctors and his dedicated caregivers Nan, Trudy, Tracy, Tammy M., Sue, Karen and Tammy T. A memorial service will be held at the Rolling Rock Club in Ligonier, PA on Saturday, September 6th at 11am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Paul's School with 'Elkus Family' in the memo section (Attn: Gifts Manager, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH, 03301, 603-229-4713) or to the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House with 'Christopher Elkus' in the memo section (Attn: Development Department, 331 East 70th Street, New York, NY 10021). The J. Paul McCraken Funeral Chapel, Inc., Ligonier, PA is assisting the family, 144 E. Main St., Ligonier, PA 15658.
